item.title: Comment on How to mock and unit test moment.js by megabyte01

item.title: Comment on How to structure your NodeJS Models by Bleh

item.description:
In reply to <a href="/how-to-structure-your-nodejs-models-2/#comment-23">Bleh</a>.
nevermind, i see it is a static method on the User function/"namespace", and the rest are instance methods on the user objects. JS is weird man.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Bleh.

nevermind, i see it is a static method on the User function/”namespace”, and the rest are instance methods on the user objects. JS is weird man.

item.title: Comment on How to structure your NodeJS Models by Anders Borg
item.dc:creator: Anders Borg
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/how-to-structure-your-nodejs-models-2/#comment-23">Bleh</a>.
What I think he means is that the user class should not have a method for getting a list of all users. A method that would return "IDs of all users this user is related to (somehow)" makes sense though. There could be a users class with user as a sub-class though.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Bleh.

What I think he means is that the user class should not have a method for getting a list of all users. A method that would return “IDs of all users this user is related to (somehow)” makes sense though. There could be a users class with user as a sub-class though.

item.title: Comment on How to structure your NodeJS Models by Bleh
item.dc:creator: Bleh
item.description:
You say that "But you donâ€™t want the method for fetching users to be part of each user because that doesnâ€™t make any sense", however it seems to me that it is still part of every user object? or am i missing something?
Thanks for the article, im new to nodejs and this defs helped to get me going with my models :)
item.content:encoded:
You say that “But you donâ€™t want the method for fetching users to be part of each user because that doesnâ€™t make any sense”, however it seems to me that it is still part of every user object? or am i missing something?

Thanks for the article, im new to nodejs and this defs helped to get me going with my models ðŸ™‚

item.title: Comment on How to structure your NodeJS Models by Anders Borg
item.dc:creator: Anders Borg
item.description: I was with you until I saw the stringify. Do you mean you are storing the whole user profile as JSON in one database cell? Can you effectively search for individual values later? I'm not using JS on the server side yet, so this looked odd to me.
item.content:encoded: I was with you until I saw the stringify. Do you mean you are storing the whole user profile as JSON in one database cell? Can you effectively search for individual values later? I’m not using JS on the server side yet, so this looked odd to me.

item.title: Comment on How to mock and unit test moment.js by Leandros
item.dc:creator: Leandros
item.description: Just stumbled onto this and I have to disagree with this implementation completely. What is happening here is that the unit test is relying on something which exists outside of the unit's world which is something that you should never care about. Instead of the unit test using the actual moment implementation you should stub getCurrentTime and return what you want in order to unit test this. This way you can test various scenarios which could be time sensitive.
item.content:encoded:
Just stumbled onto this and I have to disagree with this implementation completely.
What is happening here is that the unit test is relying on something which exists outside of the unit’s world which is something that you should never care about. Instead of the unit test using the actual moment implementation you should stub getCurrentTime and return what you want in order to unit test this. This way you can test various scenarios which could be time sensitive.
